bestBHT.bht: Let him speak as the oracles of God, speaking what he does speak as God's sayings, not his own, and realizing that his divinely inspired words are not his own, but God's. Through Christ alone can God be glorified in us and our sayings and doings. We should use the gifts and ministries entrusted to us in the church, as faithful stewards, knowing that all these things come from God through Christ and are to be rendered back to God in service to His church.

Henry Alford: speaking what he does speak, as God's sayings, not his own: as a steward
that in all things God may be glorified through Jesus Christ
is the glory and the might to the ages of the ages
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Let him speak as (becomes one speaking)
His divinely inspired words are not his own, but God's,
having them committed to him, he ought so to speak them.
God be glorified in us and our sayings and doings.
Albert Barnes: Let him speak as the oracles of God - As the oracles of God speak; to wit, in accordance with the truth which God has revealed, and with an impressive sense of the responsibility of delivering a message from him.
If any man minister...should 'minister as of the ability which God giveth'...The word may refer to any aid which we render to others in the church, as distributing alms, attending on the sick, etc.
That God in all things may be glorified - That he may be honored; to wit, by our doing all the good we can to others, and thus showing the power of his religion.
Marvin Vincent: Oracles [λογια] . In classical Greek, of the oracular responses of heathen deities. Here, divine utterances or revelations."
Peter uses the compound ejpicorhgew, furnish, in 2 Peter 1:5; which see.
John Calvin: Let him speak as the oracles of God; that is, let him reverently in God’s fear and in sincerity perform the charge committed to him, regarding himself as engaged in God’s work, and as ministering God’s word and not his own.
For he forbids any one to go forth, except he who is instructed in God’s word, and who proclaims infallible oracles as it were from his mouth.
Let him then minister as by God’s power, that is, let him regard nothing as his own, but let him humbly render service to God and his Church.
Philip Schaff: They who speak in the Church are to do so, therefore, as ‘oracles of God.’

Such gifts, however, were to be used as of the strength which God supplies, that is, with the faithfulness of stewards, and with the humility befitting men who were conscious that they drew not from stores of their own, but from what God Himself furnished.

God will be honoured ‘in all things,’ i.e. specially in all the gifts and ministries within the Church, just as Christian stewards recognise that all these things come to the Church from God through Christ, and are therefore to be rendered to God again through Christ in the form of service to His Church.
Archibald T. Robertson: Speaking as it were oracles of God.
God is the supplier of strength.
Purpose clause with ινα and the present passive subjunctive of δοξαζω. See John 15:8.
John Gill: If any man speak, let him speak as the oracles of God...and according to these he is to speak who speaks in public on divine subjects."
The matter of it must be agreeably to the divinely inspired word of God, must be fetched out of it, and confirmed by it; and he is to speak every thing that is in it, and keep back nothing."
The end of all this is, that God in all things may be glorified through Jesus Christ...all should so behave in their respective stations, as God may have glory.
John Wesley: Speak as the oracles of God — Let all his words be according to this pattern, both as to matter and manner, more especially in public.
By this mark we may always know who are, so far, the true or false prophets.

He that treats of faith and leaves out repentance, or does not enjoin practical holiness to believers, does not speak as the oracles of God: he does not preach Christ, let him think as highly of himself as he will.

bhtAttempts.bht: Let him speak as the oracles of God, speaking what he does speak as God's sayings, not his own, and realizing that his divinely inspired words are not his own, but God's. He should speak with a sense of the responsibility of delivering a message from God, as a steward entrusted with these words. Through Christ alone can God be glorified in us and our sayings and doings. In order to glorify God, we should use the gifts and ministries entrusted to us in the church, as faithful stewards, knowing that all these things come from God through Christ and are to be rendered back to God in service to His church.
